Cao, D.D. Zeng) 11 University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing (Z. Cao, D.D. Zeng)

National University of Defense Technology, Changsha (X. Lu)
metadata.abstract:
35 words
We estimate the effective reproduction number for 2019-nCoV based on the daily reported cases from China CDC. The results indicate that 2019-nCoV has a higher effective reproduction number than SARS with a comparable fatality rate.
Text—799 words

author_conclusions: In conclusion, considering transmissibility and fatality rate, 2019-nCoV poses a major public health threat, at least at the level of 2003 SARS. Epidemiological studies are critically called for to evaluate the effectiveness of stringent measures such as lockdown and help the design of refinements and development of potential alternative strategies for the next phase of the 2019-nCoV outbreak.

acknowledgments:

Technology (2016QY02D0305), National Natural Science Foundation of China (71621002, 71771213, 71790615, 71972164 and 91846301), Chinese Academy of Sciences (ZDRW-XH-

2017-3), and the Hunan Science and Technology Plan Project (2017RS3040, 2018JJ1034). Disclaimers Nil. Author Bio

Dr. Zhidong Cao is a researcher in the State Key Laboratory of Management and

Control for Complex Systems, Chinese Academy of Sciences Institute of Automation. His primary research interests are infectious disease informatics, spatio-temporal data processing, and social computing. Footnotes

introduction: Article Summary Line: This modeling study indicates that 2019-nCoV has a higher effective reproduction number than SARS with a comparable fatality rate.

We estimate the effective reproduction number for 2019-nCoV based on the daily reported cases from China CDC. The results indicate that 2019-nCoV has a higher effective reproduction number than SARS with a comparable fatality rate.

Acknowledgments: Technology (2016QY02D0305), National Natural Science Foundation of China (71621002, 71771213, 71790615, 71972164 and 91846301), Chinese Academy of Sciences (ZDRW-XH-
2017-3), and the Hunan Science and Technology Plan Project (2017RS3040, 2018JJ1034).
Author Bio: Control for Complex Systems, Chinese Academy of Sciences Institute of Automation. His primary research interests are infectious disease informatics, spatio-temporal data processing, and social computing.
References: These first authors contributed equally to this article.

participants.participant: cases with the infection dated as early as 12
participants.context: Let t denote the number of days since the start of the outbreak and Y(t) the number of cases. <mark class="stats">K is estimated based on Y(t) at six time points. (Time-1) 12/31/2019, when the authorities reported the first 27 cases with the infection dated as early as 12/16/2019</mark>. As such, t = 15, Y(15) = 27. (Time-2) 01/04/2020, t = 19, Y(19) = 41; (c) 01/21/2020, t = 36, Y(36) = 375; (Time-3) 01/22/2020, t = 37, Y(37) = 437; (Time-4) 01/23/2020, t = 38, Y

Note that the case data between 01/05/2020-01/20/2020 were discarded due to significant changes experienced in this time period in the case reporting requirements and practice. <mark class="stats">Using the data described above, R is estimated to be 4.08, indicating that an infected patient infects more than four susceptible people during the outbreak</mark>. This value substantially exceeds WHO's estimate of R0 (supposed to be smaller than R) between 1.4 and 2.5, and is also higher than a recent R0 estimate between 3.6 and 4.0 (8)

summary: Article Summary Line: This modeling study indicates that 2019-nCoV has a higher effective reproduction number than SARS with a comparable fatality rate.
R0 is the expected number of secondary infectious cases generated by an infectious case in a susceptible population.
R is the expected number of secondary cases generated by an infectious case once an epidemic is underway (6).

Following (7), R is calculated as follows: R = K2(L × D) + K(L + D) + 1, where L is the average latent period, D the average latent infectious period, K the logarithmic growth rate of the case counts as reported by China CDC.
Let t denote the number of days since the start of the outbreak and Y(t) the number of cases.
(Time-1) 12/31/2019, when the authorities reported the first 27 cases with the infection dated as early as 12/16/2019.
SARS epidemic, R of 2019-nCoV is higher than that of SARS in both Beijing (2.76) and
To predict the future outbreak profile, the authors developed a model based on the deterministic Susceptible-Exposed-Infectious-Recovered-Death-Cumulative (SEIRDC)
The authors' model appears to explain the reported case counts very well during the current early stage of the outbreak.
An interesting finding is that by setting the start date to a time earlier than 12/16/2020, the SEIRDC model is able to provide a better fit for the case counts.

This indicates that human-to-human transmission may have started earlier than what the current prevailing is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.
The SEIRDC model estimates the fatality rate for 2019-nCoV is 6.50%.
The authors used the model to predict the confirmed case counts and death counts in the first 80 days of the ongoing 2019-nCoV outbreak.
The authors simulated these counts for the 2003 SARS outbreaks in Beijing and Guangzhou as well, using the case counts as input.
At the end of this 80-day period, according to the simulations, the 2019-nCoV case counts
The 2019-nCoV death count (1,089) is much higher than that of SARS in
The authors' study suggests that by reducing the average infectious period to <2.3 days, the resulting R will decease to a value less than 1, meaning the epidemic can be effectively controlled.
Considering transmissibility and fatality rate, 2019-nCoV poses a major public health threat, at least at the level of 2003 SARS.

Epidemiological studies are critically called for to evaluate the effectiveness of stringent measures such as lockdown and help the design of refinements and development of potential alternative strategies for the phase of the 2019-nCoV outbreak.

The authors' study suggests that by reducing the average infectious period to <2.3 days, the resulting R will decease to a value less than 1, meaning the epidemic can be effectively controlled.
Considering transmissibility and fatality rate, 2019-nCoV poses a major public health threat, at least at the level of 2003 SARS.
